and a book about the letter
Clap your hands when you hear a word that begins with the /l/ sound.
Touch your shoulders when you hear a word that begins with the /l/ sound.
Model writing uppercase and lowercase letters
Provide drawing and writing supplies. Guide children in practicing forming their letters
, stop at each word that begins with the letter
. Have children say /k/ and the word that begins with
. For children who need assistance, before writing have them trace letters in salt or sand. repeat with the second sound.
Encourage children to name additional words that begin with
If they suggest a word that begins with
but has the /k/ sound, congratulate them on naming a word that begins with /k/. Then challenge children to name animals whose names begin like
When reviewing the letter sounds for
by saying different words that begin with those sounds, always respond by repeating the letter sounds and names. For example: After a child answers that
begins with the sound /k/.” Hold up a
letter card and say “/k/ is the sound of the letter

To help children with auditory discrimination challenges, exaggerate the movements of your mouth as you form each letter sound, being mindful of your tongue and lip positions. Do this while saying the sound in isolation and again as you say the sound within the picture word. Invite children to move their mouths in the same way as they make the letter sound.

(uppercase and lowercase), box for cards, Pablo the Parrot Puppet
We noticed how the two brothers focused their attention on one object at a time.
When we focus our attention, we keep looking, listening, or doing something even if something interrupts us for a bit.

Before, we played “What’s Missing?” You had to look at a set of objects. Then you hid your eyes, and I took away an object. When you opened your eyes, you had to figure out what was missing. Now let’s play the game with our letter cards.
Present the following uppercase letter cards:
, Invite children to point to and name the letters.
Remove one letter and put it back in the box of letter cards.
Then tell children they can open their eyes.
Who can tell me what letter is missing? Who can find that letter in the box?
Choose one child to find the missing letter and place it where it belongs. Then have everyone say the letters together.
Continue with different letters and with lowercase letters.
What is fun about finding what is missing?

Decrease the number of letters in the span to three to make the task easier. Also, make sure children know the names of the letters before you remove any of the letters. Children may need extra reminders about focusing their attention on the task.

Increase the number of letters in the spans when you play the game. Also, you may try removing two letters at a time and see if children can name the missing letters. Challenge children to name words that begin with each letter.
Make sure children know the names of the letters in English before you begin the activity. Present the letters from
and have them name them in order. When you do the activity, help children name the letters.

If a child needs an extra reminder about focusing their attention on the task, encourage the child by saying such things as, “I can see Max is paying attention,” “I like the way you are keeping your eyes hidden,” or “I think you are going to be able to figure out what letter is missing.”
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
It’s so much fun to listen to and look at books. There is so much to think about and learn.
Now, we’re going to look at some of the books we have in our Library and Listening Corner.
Each of you will choose a book.
You will look through the book.
Then you will have a turn to tell us about your book.
Demonstrate the activity with one of the Alphabet Books. First ask children to show and tell you how to hold the book. Then show how you look through the book. And finally tell about the book.
Ask the first child to choose a book and show the book to the group.
What letter is on the cover of the book you chose? Why did you choose this book? Look at pictures. What is the story about?
Accept all book comments and compliment children on the way they read.
Continue choosing one child at a time to choose, show, and share her book.
Why is it fun to “read” to a favorite doll or stuffed animal?
How can we take good care of our books?

Once a child has chosen a book, they may need help in holding it correctly. Then scaffold the retelling by helping children tell about the pictures on one page at a time. Prompt children by asking whey they see and what is happening.
Challenge children to “read” the book, page by page, to the group as if they were the teacher. Encourage children to have fun with this activity and compliment all their efforts.

You may want to partner children for this activity. Have the partners choose the book together, share the book, and then talk about what is happening in the story. Then invite the child who is most comfortable to relate the story to the group.

Invite children to share their ideas about what is the most comfortable way for them to hold their books and turn the pages. Help children find the way—it might be flat on the desk, in their laps, or in their hands with their elbows on the table.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Empty cube-shaped tissue boxes and various small items, one for each sense (for example, bell/hear; cotton balls/touch; cinnamon stick/smell; picture of a cloud/see)
One brother in this story uses mostly his sense of sight to tell about or explain things. The other uses his senses of hearing, smell, and touch.
In this activity, we will use one sense to learn about what is in each mystery box. I will pass around a box and we will use our senses to tell about it. Are you ready for the mystery boxes?
Pass the first mystery box around the table.
Reach in the box and use only your sense of touch. Think about how the object feels.
What do you feel? What do you think is in this mystery box?
After everyone has a chance to guess, reveal the cotton ball in the box.
We used our sense of touch. We felt the softness and knew it was a cotton ball.
Continue investigating one mystery box at a time, emphasizing the one sense you are asking children to use.
Review with the children all the senses they used and what items they explored. Ask questions, such as:
Which sense did you use to learn about the cinnamon stick?
What senses can we not use to explore clouds?

Support children by reminding them that they are only using one sense. After naming the sense, invite them to point to the body part they will be using to find out what’s in the mystery box. Use expressions like “hear with your ears,” or “taste with your mouth.”

After you do the activity, invite children to name other items that might be good for each mystery box—things to see, things to hear, things to taste, things to smell, and things to touch. Ask them if they would like to do the activity again with other items. Repeat if possible.

Help multilingual learners more easily participate in the mystery box activity by asking them to name the object in their home language and then telling the name of the object in English. Don’t preview the items to name them because that would detract from the surprise.

Do not insist that students with sensory issues touch, smell, or taste any given item unless they choose to do so on their own. Instead, focus on how other sense(s) can provide lots of information as well.
